It was Day 72. But clearly many more days of recovery lay ahead.

‘I want to see the next Black Wall Street in Boston’: Segun Idowu is a man of the momentAt just 31, Segun Idowu already has a career as an organizer behind him, from street protests to the campaign to bring body cameras to Boston police. Now, just 20 months into his role as the executive director of the Black Economic Council of Massachusetts (BECMA), Idowu has emerged as a singular voice of the moment.

The pandemic has people reexamining their lives. Some don’t like what they’re seeingIf an entire region can have an existential crisis, we’re doing it right now. Spouses are being left, retirements pushed up, friends dropped. People are moving to rural spots and strengthening their faith, and those fortunate enough to have a choice are saying “no” to commuting.

‘I want to see the next Black Wall Street in Boston’: Segun Idowu is a man of the momentAt just 31, Segun Idowu already has a career as an organizer behind him, from street protests to the campaign to bring body cameras to Boston police. Now, just 20 months into his role as the executive director of the Black Economic Council of Massachusetts (BECMA), Idowu has emerged as a singular voice of the moment.

The pandemic has people reexamining their lives. Some don’t like what they’re seeingIf an entire region can have an existential crisis, we’re doing it right now. Spouses are being left, retirements pushed up, friends dropped. People are moving to rural spots and strengthening their faith, and those fortunate enough to have a choice are saying “no” to commuting.

People are moving to rural spots and strengthening their faith, and those fortunate enough to have a choice are saying “no” to commuting.
